ns:common.document.text:
This article in a nutshell: The Lisp programming language has been growing in popularity after 2000 despite a lack of interest throughout the mid to late 1990s, so the term "Lisp renaissance" has been applied loosely in conversation to describe this trend (e.g., within full text of  and    

Increases in Lisp programming language usage during 2000s is measured partly by sales from the print version of Peter Seibel's Practical Common Lisp book , which is of particular note due to also having full text available on-line freely available in various formats. 

Additional factors are higher attendance of related conferences or analysing newsgroup postings. 

As contemporary programmers delve into learning and mastering Lisp, they're likely to cite efficiency characteristics from the comparison of languages by Peter Norvig, author of Paradigms of AI Programming: Case Studies in Common Lisp and Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach. However, more current performance figures should be based upon The Computer Language Benchmarks Game or individual exercises such as a challenge posted on [news:comp.lang.lisp comp.lang.lisp] in 2004 or following speed gains of an individual
